author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Newton N. Minow, F.C.C. Chief Who Deemed TV a ‘Vast Wasteland,’ Dies at 97
description: His stunning declaration caused an instant sensation when he made it in 1961 and ignited a national debate over Americans’ viewing habits.
content: Newton N. Minow, who as President John F. Kennedy’s new F.C.C. chairman in 1961 sent shock waves through an industry and touched a nerve in a nation addicted to banality and mayhem by calling American television “a vast wasteland,” died on Saturday at his home in Chicago . He was 97.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Erika Kemp Wants to See More Runners Who Look Like Her
description: Kemp, who had a solid marathon debut in Boston during a race with racial controversy on the sidelines, did not run cross-country until college. “There wasn’t anyone that looked like me.”
content: The video of local police officers forming a bicycle blockade in front of a group of Black supporters during this year’s Boston Marathon seemed to highlight once again some unpleasant truths about running in America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas and Alexandra Glorioso
title: DeSantis to Visit Wisconsin, a 2024 Battleground, as He Circles Trump
description: The Florida governor, who has slipped in polls as his expected entrance to the presidential race nears, is moving beyond early nominating states like Iowa and New Hampshire.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida is expanding his political travel as his poll numbers slip ahead of an expected presidential campaign, visiting rural north-central Wisconsin on Saturday in a sign of his intent to compete for voters beyond early nominating states like Iowa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Supremely Arrogant
description: Are these men interpreting the law or settling scores?
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court is still great.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Coronation Briefing
description: A special edition on King Charles III.
content: This morning, King Charles III will be crowned as sovereign of the United Kingdom in the nation’s first coronation in 70 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: It’s Coronation Day
description: Come for the crown jewels and gold stagecoach; stay for the questions about the monarchy’s relevance.
content: On the “how interested are you in the royal family?” spectrum, which runs from antipathy to adoration, I’m in the mildly curious range: I know who the major players are; I watched the Harry and Meghan documentary but not “The Crown.” I cannot help but feel some affinity with a person (Queen Elizabeth II) who allegedly invented an indisputably adorable dog breed (the dorgi, a cross between a dachshund and a Welsh corgi).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: ‘It’s in Our Culture’: Serbia Reflects on Gun Ownership Tradition After Shootings
description: Back-to-back massacres have forced the country, still in mourning, to grapple with its complicated and long gun tradition.
content: In Serbia, where guns are so prolific they are a regular part of wedding and birthday celebrations, two mass shootings in two days have led to a reckoning about the role of deadly weapons in the culture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Sexton
title: A Tragedy in Omaha
description: Some tragedies can offer communities a chance to heal together. But that’s hard in 21st-century America.
content: OMAHA — By nightfall on May 30, 2020, Jake Gardner was inside his nightclub in Omaha’s Old Market district. He had handguns and a shotgun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar and Anton Troianovski
title: Car Bombing Injures Prominent Russian Nationalist Writer, State Media Reports
description: Zakhar Prilepin, who himself fought in eastern Ukraine, has long advocated an imperialist foreign policy by Moscow.
content: A car bombing on Saturday seriously wounded a prominent Russian nationalist and novelist, while killing his driver, state media reported, one of a series of internal attacks that are spreading a sense of disarray even as the country gears up to celebrate its most important annual military holiday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Sea Change
description: Will Nediger’s Sunday puzzle evolves as it’s solved.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Nothing Is Bigger Than Stephen Curry vs. LeBron James
description: Curry and James are meeting in the playoffs, perhaps for the last time. Together and apart, they have redefined a generation of basketball.
content: Tim Hardaway knows stars when he sees them. Hardaway, a Hall of Fame point guard, battled against his share of them, including Michael Jordan, during a 14-year N.B.A. career.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sonne and Andrew E. Kramer
title: As Putin Bides His Time, Ukraine Faces a Ticking Clock
description: Ukraine is feeling short-term pressure from its Western backers for success in a looming counteroffensive. Vladimir Putin seems to be operating on a longer timeline.
content: Both armies have tanks, artillery and tens of thousands of soldiers ready to face off on the battlefields of Ukraine in a long-anticipated Ukrainian counteroffensive against Russia. But one thing clearly sets the two sides apart: time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Travelli and Suhasini Raj
title: Dozens Killed in Ethnic Clashes in India’s Manipur State
description: Violence erupted over a question of who gets to claim special tribal status.
content: Clashes between rival ethnic groups in Manipur, a remote state in India’s northeast, have reportedly killed dozens of people in recent days, and the situation remains volatile, even as the authorities rush troops to the area to quell the disorder and seek to control the flow of information.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Barnard
title: A Senior Tradition You Might Not Know About
description: Senior cords, which feature hand-drawn details, first appeared on campuses in Indiana. Now there are high-fashion takes.
content: The fashion designer Emily Adams Bode Aujla bought her first pair of senior corduroy pants from a vintage-clothing seller in 2013 when she was a senior at the New School. The pants style had by then been around for more than a century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn and Peter Eavis
title: Backup Power: A Growing Need, if You Can Afford It
description: Extreme weather linked to climate change is causing more blackouts. But generators and batteries are still out of reach for many.
content: When frigid weather caused rolling blackouts on Christmas Eve across North Carolina, Eliana and David Mundula quickly grew worried about their 2½-week-old daughter, whom they had brought home days earlier from a neonatal intensive care unit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: Canadians greet the coronation with a muted response.
description: The king’s representative in Canada, where he is head of state, recently appealed to people in the country to “give him a chance.”
content: TORONTO — Despite his status as Canada’s head of state, only modest festivities have been planned this weekend for the coronation of King Charles III in the country’s capital, Ottawa, and turnout is predicted to be much lower than is typical for other Canadian public celebrations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Missed the Coronation? Here’s What Happened, From the Crown to the Crowds.
description: The lavish ceremony for Britain’s first new reigning monarch in 70 years, was brimming with ancient traditions with a few modern touches.
content: Setting the theme of the resplendent yet intimate-for-a-royal-coronation ceremony, King Charles III’s first remarks at the beginning of the two-hour spectacle at Westminster Abbey were, “I come not to be served, but to serve.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: A Tennis Match That’s Also a College Program’s Farewell
description: The men’s tennis team at St. Francis of Brooklyn just finished its best season with a trip to the N.C.A.A. tournament. Soon, the college will have no sports programs at all.
content: On an overcast day, before a few dozen people at the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center, a team of players wearing light blue uniforms battles a team in dark blue across six courts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
title: Charles is Jamaica’s head of state. The island nation may break with the monarchy next year.
description: The Commonwealth country has scheduled a referendum in 2024 on whether to cut ties to the British monarchy, opening up a debate on how to reshape the society.
content: As King Charles III put on the centuries-old St. Edward’s crown on Saturday, Jamaica, a Commonwealth member, continued to move ahead with plans to cut ties with the British monarchy — a decision scheduled for a referendum in 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Menahem Pressler, Pianist Who Co-Founded the Beaux Arts Trio, Dies at 99
description: Mr. Pressler, who fled Nazi Germany as a youth, was the anchor of a group that, with various lineups, performed all over the world for 53 years.
content: Menahem Pressler, the celebrated pianist who fled Nazi Germany in 1939 and, after establishing himself in postwar America, co-founded the Beaux Arts Trio, which became the world’s reigning piano-violin-cello ensemble and dazzled audiences for a half-century, died on Saturday in London. He was 99.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Howard Fishman
title: Before Dylan, There Was Connie Converse. Then She Vanished.
description: There’s a resurgence of interest in the pioneering singer-songwriter who disappeared when she was 50.
content: Connie Converse was a pioneer of what’s become known as the singer-songwriter era, making music in the predawn of a movement that had its roots in the Greenwich Village folk scene of the early 1960s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lazaro Gamio
title: Here’s King Charles’s Coronation Route Through London
description: His route is markedly shorter than the one taken by Queen Elizabeth II in 1953.
content: King Charles III’s route through London ran down the Mall from Buckingham Palace toward Trafalgar Square, and then down Whitehall, past the Palace of Westminster and Big Ben, before ending at Westminster Abbey for the coronation ceremony.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: Choreographed Formality, Like an Elaborate Masque
description: As in ballet, the coronation provided spectacle and beauty tempered by discipline and focus.
content: About 40 minutes into the coronation of King Charles III, six officers in red tunics solemnly placed three embroidered screens on the mosaic floor of Westminster Abbey. They stood still for a moment, then moved the screens in perfect unison to form a tight shelter from the eyes of the public. To the propulsive strains of Handel’s “Zadok the Priest,” each man dropped an arm to his side, took a step sideways and fell into another perfect formation — two angled inward on each side, framed by two men facing out. Then, as one, they bowed their heads.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What’s on Students’ Minds: School Shootings, Trans Bias, Content Warnings and More
description: It’s our annual letter-writing competition. The envelope, please!
content: We invited high school students to write a letter to the editor about a recent Times article. Here are some of our favorite submissions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Amount of Resistance
description: Carter Cobb’s second Times puzzle makes us travel through the abyss.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This grid, Carter Cobb’s second construction for The New York Times after a Friday debut in March, is a crossword statistician’s delight. It reaches for at least three superlatives. First, it is what’s known as “wide open,” meaning that a high number of its white squares do not touch a black square, even diagonally. (In this case, that number is 122, which puts the puzzle in rarefied company.) Second, there are only 21 black squares, also known as blocks. (Apparently, a low block count is an obsessive pursuit of many constructors.) Finally, the words in this puzzle are so lively and unusual that its fill has a “freshness factor” in the 96.3 percentile of Times grids.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Bradley and Euan Ward
title: As king, Charles inherits untold riches, and passes control of his own vast holdings to William.
description: King Charles III built his own empire long before he inherited his mother’s: He spent half a century turning his royal estate into a billion-dollar portfolio and one of the most lucrative moneymakers in the royal family business.
content: King Charles III built his own empire long before he inherited his mother’s: He spent half a century turning his royal estate into a billion-dollar portfolio and one of the most lucrative moneymakers in the royal family business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Don Sebesky, Arranger Who Helped Broaden Jazz’s Audience, Dies at 85
description: He won Tonys for his orchestrations and Grammys for his compositions and arrangements. But he was best known for his genre-straddling work at CTI Records.
content: Don Sebesky, who in a wide-ranging musical career played with leading big bands, was a behind-the-scenes force at CTI Records and other jazz labels, won Grammy Awards for his own compositions and arrangements, and orchestrated some 20 Broadway shows, died on April 29 at a nursing home in Maplewood, N.J. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Anti-monarchists see an opportunity to prove their point in the coronation events.
description: Supporters of an elected head of state for Britain see the coronation as an opportunity to highlight the absurdity of having a royal family in the 21st century.
content: While some Britons prepared for King Charles III’s coronation by buying royal paraphernalia or cooking for street parties, a 21-year-old student in the northern city of Leeds instead ordered 50 beach balls bearing the words “No more royals.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Share Your Thoughts on the Crowning of King Charles III
description: The New York Times invites readers to share their comments and observations about the coronation of Britain’s King Charles III.
content: As The New York Times covers the crowning of King Charles III, Britain’s first new monarch in 70 years, we invite readers to share their comments here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Deonn
title: 6 Great Y.A. Fantasy Novels
description: Tracy Deonn, the Coretta Scott King-John Steptoe Award-winning author of “Legendborn” and “Bloodmarked,” recommends a few of her favorite young adult fantasy titles.
content: My favorite fantasy stories run on possibility. Not only what might happen to a character, but what they can make happen. If you need a reminder that life is not set in stone, here are six expansive and empowering young adult fantasy books that show us that real people are capable of extraordinary things.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Coronation Fashion: Queen Camilla, Princess Catherine and Clothes Full of Meaning
description: Why a dress is never just a dress at a major occasion of State.
content: Is there any pageant of state more chockablock with symbolism than a royal coronation? Almost every detail, from the crown itself to the “bracelets of sincerity and wisdom” presented to the new monarch, is redolent of meaning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peggy O'Donnell Heffington
title: Why Women Not Having Kids Became a Panic
description: History is full of women without children
content: In America today, we tend to talk about not having children as a late-20th-century phenomenon made possible by contraceptive technology and women’s liberation. If you listen to a lot of politicians and public figures, you’d think that being childless was invented by millennials as another way of shirking our duty to society.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Asked About Age, Biden Says He Knows ‘More Than the Vast Majority of People’
description: The president also said that he was not yet prepared to lean on the 14th Amendment to compel the government to pay its debt amid a showdown with House Republicans.
content: In his first interview since announcing that he would seek a second term, President Biden sought to downplay concerns about his age by saying he was the most experienced person to have ever run for the presidency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Can My Building Force Me to Use Its Preferred Moving Company?
description: Some landlords only want trusted movers in the building. But what does the lease say about it?
content: Q: I live in a high-rise luxury rental building on the Upper East Side. Recently, building management sent out a “welcome package” that included a rule requiring tenants to use one of three approved moving companies for moves in or out of the building. I plan on moving out when my lease expires. Am I really obligated to hire one of these companies even though I’m signing the contract and paying workers who will be moving my personal belongings into another property?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Washington, Josh Katz and Tom Giratikanon
title: Top 10 Hardest and Easiest Spelling Bee Words, April 29-May 5
description: A word related to milk was hard to draw out. On the other side of the spectrum, many saw the “light.”
content: This week, lacteal — which means “relating to, or consisting of, milk” — was the word least found by players of Spelling Bee, while light was the most found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: The Coronation of King Charles III, in Pictures
description: As Britain’s King Charles III is crowned, here’s a selection of the best photographs from the coronation weekend.
content: The British monarchy, according to the Victorian writer Walter Bagehot, “is commonly hidden like a mystery, and sometimes paraded like a pageant.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Kornelis
title: Diane Keaton Likes a Messy Comedy
description: The Oscar-winning actress and one of the stars of “Book Club: The Next Chapter” makes friends when making movies and is trying to get to the beach.
content: One of Diane Keaton’s new favorite pastimes is going for walks by herself, taking pictures of abandoned storefronts.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Families at Work and Play Beneath Toxic Clouds
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, May 6, 2023.
content: “When the smell comes, all we can really do is try to keep everyone inside. Is that enough? I just don’t know.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gregory Cowles
title: Journaling, Appetites and a Movie Star’s Private Life
description: An editor recommends old and new books.
content: Molly Young is on leave for the next several months. In her absence, colleagues from the Book Review will pick up the recommendation torch and appear in your inbox every two Saturdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: It’s Beginning to Feel a Lot Like 2016 Again
description: Things are different, but maybe not enough.
content: Around the time that Donald Trump announced his presidential campaign, there was a lot of chatter about how anti-Trump Republicans were poised to repeat the failures of 2016, by declining to take on Trump directly and letting him walk unscathed to the nomination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape
title: Forte, the morning-line favorite, was scratched hours before the race.
description: The colt was taken out of the field with a bruised hoof at the end of a difficult week for the Derby and the sport.
content: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — State veterinarians on Saturday morning scratched Forte, the favorite to win the Kentucky Derby, after examining him and finding him unfit to compete because of a bruise on his right front hoof. Rumors that the colt was unwell had swirled throughout Churchill Downs over the week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Lauren McCarthy
title: More Than 24,500 Are Evacuated as Wildfires Burn in Western Canada
description: Government officials declared a provincial state of emergency as more than 100 wildfires burned across Alberta on Saturday, with dozens still “out of control.”
content: Officials in the western Canadian province of Alberta declared a provincial state of emergency on Saturday after more than 24,500 people had to evacuate their homes because of rampant wildfires.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola and Megan Specia
title: The London police, with new powers against ‘serious disruption,’ arrest dozens of protesters.
description: Prior to the coronation, the police had said that there would be little tolerance for disruptive protests. On the day itself, more than 50 people were arrested, most on offenses that appeared to be connected to protests.
content: London’s Metropolitan Police said they arrested 52 people on Saturday, most for offenses that appeared connected to the coronation of Charles III, including public order offenses, breach of the peace and conspiracy to cause a public nuisance. In the afternoon, the police said that all those arrested remained in custody.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: Charles III Was Crowned King. But Can He Ever Be the Star?
description: On Saturday, Charles finally became the focal figure of the long-running royal TV drama — if only for a day.
content: It is always a challenge to introduce a major cast change in a long-running serial. Saturday morning, in a special episode with elements of “The Crown” and “Succession,” King Charles III finally became the focal figure of the royal ensemble — if only for a day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: In Australia, He Was a ‘Great Father.’ Secretly, He Was an Escaped Convict.
description: New DNA evidence helped confirm that a man who went by John Damon and died in Australia in 2010 was actually William Leslie Arnold, a convicted killer and escaped inmate from Nebraska.
content: A grave marker at Tamborine Mountain Cemetery in Queensland, Australia, bears the name John Vincent Damon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Caldwell
title: The First Scandal King Charles Could Face Is a Gift From Boris Johnson
description: Appointing people to the House of Lords can be complicated.
content: At his coronation in London on Saturday, King Charles III will assume the ancient responsibilities of the British monarchy. The king is not just a ruler. He is also a fons honorum — a “fount of honor,” charged with preserving the reverence his subjects feel for their governing institutions. One of the ways he does this is by literally ennobling worthy Britons, entitling them to sit in the House of Lords. Historically, membership in the Lords has been hereditary. Today, new members are “life peers” whose titles cannot be passed on. They are appointed by the king following an “honors list” of recommendations made up by the prime minister.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawna Richer
title: Gordon Lightfoot’s Death Is a Loss That Feels Personal
description: Lightfoot’s music created the soundtrack for the daily life of many Canadian families.
content: When I was growing up, Gordon Lightfoot songs played on the living room stereo, on the radio in the kitchen and in the family car and on my dad’s guitar so continuously that it felt like the Canadian singer-songwriter, who died in a Toronto hospital on Monday at 84, lived with us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora, Eric Schmitt and John Ismay
title: Ukraine Claims It Shot Down Russia’s Most Sophisticated Missile for First Time
description: The air force said it intercepted the hypersonic missile with a newly delivered U.S.-made Patriot air-defense battery. U.S. officials confirmed the strike.
content: An American-made Patriot air-defense missile successfully intercepted one of the most sophisticated conventional weapons in Russia’s arsenal for the first time over Kyiv on Thursday night, the Ukrainian air force claimed on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: Even with a heavy crown, Camilla seems lighter in her new role.
description: The coronation was not just the moment Charles finally ascended to a role in wait for his whole life, but also the final act in the long rehabilitation of the former Camilla Parker Bowles.
content: First she was the royal mistress, reviled by much of Britain for her role as spoiler in the doomed marriage of Charles and his first wife, the late Diana, Princess of Wales. (“There were three of us in this marriage,” Diana declared in 1995, “so it was a bit crowded.”)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller and Sarah Kliff
title: Unwanted Epidurals, Untreated Pain: Black Women Tell Their Birth Stories
description: Regardless of income or education, Black mothers have worse birth outcomes.
content: When Afrika Gupton-Jones was on bed rest in the hospital, after developing high blood pressure at 28 weeks of pregnancy, her husband was with her day and night. Yet the nurses often assumed that he was her brother, and that she was a single mother. When the doctors and nurses gave her medications or took her blood, she said, they gave her minimal explanation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aric Toler, Robin Stein, Glenn Thrush, Riley Mellen and Ishaan Jhaveri
title: War, Weapons and Conspiracy Theories: Inside Airman Teixeira’s Online World
description: A review of more than 9,500 messages obtained by The New York Times offers important clues about the mind-set of a young airman implicated in a vast leak of government secrets.
content: Jack Teixeira, the Air National Guardsman implicated in a vast leak of classified documents, was fixated on weapons, mass shootings, shadowy conspiracy theories — and proving he was in the right, and in the know.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: What Will Happen During the Coronation
description: After the coronation service at Westminster Abbey, King Charles III and other members of the royal family will make an appearance on the balcony of Buckingham Palace.
content: King Charles III, Britain’s first new monarch in 70 years, was crowned on Saturday in a ceremony at Westminster Abbey in London.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Bank Turmoil Is Paving the Way for Even Bigger ‘Shadow Banks’
description: The market for loans from non-bank firms like Apollo and Blackstone is booming. A crisis in regional lenders could accelerate it.
content: Whipsaw trading in shares of regional banks this week made it clear the fallout from three federal bank seizures was far from over. Some investors are betting against even seemingly healthy banks like PacWest, and regulators are gearing up to tack on new capital constraints for small and medium-size lenders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Michigan School District Bans Backpacks Over Safety Concerns
description: Officials in Flint were alarmed by threats to students’ safety. The ban is in effect at least until the end of the school year.
content: On the back of a door in a home in Flint, Mich., there hangs a black Trailmaker backpack that belongs to Jaxon Williams, a third grader at Freeman Elementary. It hasn’t been moved for nearly a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Angwin
title: Few Are Addressing One of Social Media’s Greatest Perils
description: Fear-inciting speech, which isn’t banned by the big tech platforms, is far more dangerous than hate speech.
content: This year, Facebook and Twitter allowed a video of a talk to be distributed on their platforms in which Michael J. Knowles, a right-wing pundit, called for “transgenderism” to be “eradicated.” The Conservative Political Action Coalition, which hosted the talk, said in its social media posts promoting the video that the talk was “all about the left’s attempt to erase biological women from modern society.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter and Elizabeth A. Harris
title: Asked to Delete References to Racism From Her Book, an Author Refused
description: The case, involving Scholastic, led to an outcry among authors and became an example of how the culture wars behind a surge in book banning in schools has reached publishers.
content: It was the most personal story that Maggie Tokuda-Hall had ever written: the tale of how her grandparents met and fell in love at an incarceration camp in Idaho that held Japanese Americans during World War II.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Judith Miller, ‘Antiques Roadshow’ Mainstay, Is Dead at 71
description: Known for her many guidebooks, she helped determine what was trash and what was treasure on the BBC series that inspired the American show.
content: Judith Miller, the author of popular antiques price guides and a member of the team of appraisers who determined what was trash and what was treasure on “Antiques Roadshow,” the beloved long-running BBC program that inspired the American series of the same name, died on April 8 in North London. She was 71.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 6, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, May 6, 2023.
content: An article on Thursday about a seventh-grade student who opened fire at a school in Serbia misstated the number of people killed after a wedding in Serbia in 2015. Six people were killed, not four.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: One Photographer’s Challenge: To Turn King Charles III Into an Icon
description: Hugo Burnand is the coronation’s official portrait photographer. He will have just moments to capture an image of the newly crowned British monarch for the history books.
content: Hundreds of photographers will spend Saturday trying to capture the perfect image of the coronation. But one faces a tougher task: to turn King Charles III into an icon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Were Will and Kate Late to the Coronation? The News Media Wonders.
description: The Prince and Princess of Wales arrived at Westminster Abbey after King Charles III, prompting speculation among the many journalists covering the ceremony.
content: Where were the Waleses?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: The Despair Fueling America’s Chronic Pain
description: Millions are suffering in ways that lead to addiction, sorrow and a tangle of other pathologies. Why?
content: One of the mysteries of America is why so many people are in pain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Lewis Capaldi Will Break Your Heart. (But Don’t Take Him Too Seriously.)
description: The joke-cracking Scottish musician’s melodramatic ballad “Someone You Loved” is a blockbuster. Figuring out his next moves became more complicated than he’d anticipated.
content: The first thing you have to know about Lewis Capaldi is that he is kidding. The Scottish musician, who specializes in pop treacle, is foulmouthed the way a young child is — cheekily and cuddly, without a fleck of harm. He is anti-piety, a bloke on a punchline bender. Almost everything he says is accompanied by a wink.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Hoppert
title: Here’s something most racing fans agree on: 50 years later, Secretariat is still the GOAT.
description: A record-setting Triple Crown run was such an achievement that it helped the horse known as Big Red serve as “a rallying cry for America.”
content: Before he was “moving like a tremendous machine” in a literal earth-shattering performance in the Belmont Stakes, before he secured the ninth Triple Crown sweep in history, ending a 25-year drought, Secretariat won the Kentucky Derby in such dramatic fashion that it would be considered one of the greatest races of all time — if only he didn’t follow it with even greater theatrics in his next two races.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Beth Gahan, Remy Tumin, Claire Fahy and Lauren McCarthy
title: At Least 9 Dead, Including Gunman, in Shooting at Texas Mall
description: A police officer on an unrelated assignment nearby rushed toward the sounds of gunfire and killed the gunman.
content: A gunman opened fire at a crowded mall outside Dallas on Saturday, killing at least eight people and injuring at least seven before a police officer killed him, the authorities said, turning a busy afternoon of shopping into a chaotic and tragic scene.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: Once Close, William and Harry Are Now Rows Apart
description: The sons of King Charles III did not appear to interact during their father’s coronation.
content: They were once so close. And so it was striking, and a little sad, to see how far Charles’s two sons — Prince Harry, the Duke of Sussex, and Prince William, the Prince of Wales — have drifted apart in the past few years. William had an official role in Saturday’s coronation, as the heir to the throne; Harry had none at all, except as a relative demoted to the third row of Westminster Abbey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: ‘Like He Was Going to Live Forever’: Making Jerome Robbins’s Last Ballet
description: His exuberant “Brandenburg,” which returns to City Ballet this month, was made near the end of his life, when he was physically and emotionally frail.
content: Jerome Robbins wasn’t feeling well in winter 1995. He had created “West Side Story Suite” — a condensed adaptation of his 1957 hit Broadway musical — for New York City Ballet earlier that year and started work on a new pas de deux with two principal dancers, Lourdes Lopez and Nikolaj Hübbe. By December, it was clear that he needed heart surgery. In the next months, he began to show symptoms that suggested Parkinson’s disease and had a bad fall that affected his balance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Charles Is Crowned King in Ancient Ceremony With Modern Twists
description: The coronation, the first since Queen Elizabeth II’s in 1953, was a royal spectacle of the kind that only Britain still stages.
content: Anointed with holy oil and enthroned on St. Edward’s chair, King Charles III was crowned on Saturday in a solemn ritual that stretches back more than a millennium but unfolded with multiple concessions to the modern age.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neelam Bohra
title: Hearing Aids Are Changing. Their Users Are, Too.
description: As more young people risk hearing loss, over-the-counter hearing aids are providing new options, but also confusing choices.
content: Ayla Wing’s middle school students don’t always know what to make of their 26-year-old teacher’s hearing aids. The most common response she hears: “Oh, my grandma has them, too.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Demonization of the Homeless Has Vile Consequences
description: Subway cars should not be homes — or deathbeds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: Berkshire Reports Big Jump in Earnings
description: Gains in its insurance business offset lower revenue from its real estate and consumer products companies. The results came out at the start of the conglomerate’s 59th annual meeting.
content: Berkshire Hathaway on Saturday reported a sixfold jump in its first-quarter earnings, buoyed by huge paper gains on investments, as the conglomerate led by Warren E. Buffett held its annual shareholder meeting in Omaha, its hometown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: What DeSantis Signed in Florida
description: Here are five notable bills the governor and presidential aspirant has signed or is expected to sign.
content: Here are five notable bills the governor and presidential aspirant has signed or is expected to sign.
source.name: The New York Times
